S1.T1.caption: Table I: Comparison for central privacy under: (1) orthogonal and (2) wireless aggregation transmissions.
S1.T1.table:
Transmission scheme Without sampling With sampling
Orthogonal ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğ’ª1\mathcal{O}(1) [30] ğ’ªâ€‹(1/K)ğ’ª1ğ¾\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{K}) [24]
Wireless Aggregation ğ’ªâ€‹(1/K)ğ’ª1ğ¾\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{K}) [26] ğ’ªâ€‹(1/K3/4)ğ’ª1superscriptğ¾34{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\mathcal{O}(1/K^{3/4})} (Lemma 1)
references:
Main Contributions: In this paper, we consider the problem of FedSGD training over Gaussian multiple access channels (MACs), subject to LDP and DP constraints. We propose a wireless FedSGD scheme with user sampling, where users are sampled uniformly or based on their channel conditions. We then study analog aggregation schemes coupled with the proposed sampling schemes, in which each user transmits a linear combination of (a)ğ‘(a) local gradient and (b)ğ‘(b) artificial Gaussian noise. The local gradients are processed as a function of the channel gains to align the resulting gradients at the PS, whereas the artificial noise parameters are selected to satisfy the privacy constraints. The existing privacy analysis in [24, 25] for FL with user sampling cannot be applied to our problem. The key challenge is that in each training iteration, the effective noise seen at the signal received by the PS over the wireless channel is a function of a random number of sampled users, making the DP/LDP analysis non-trivial. Using concentration inequalities, we prove that the central privacy leakage scales as ğ’ªâ€‹(1/K3/4)ğ’ª1superscriptğ¾34\mathcal{O}(1/K^{3/4}) with wireless aggregation and user sampling. We also provide convergence analysis of the proposed scheme for different sampling schemes.
To the best of our knowledge, this is the first result on wireless FedSGD with LDP and DP constraints with user sampling (see Table I for comparison).

The proof of Lemma 1 is presented in Appendix C. From Lemma 1, we observe that the central privacy level behaves as ğ’ªâ€‹(1/K3/4)ğ’ª1superscriptğ¾34\mathcal{O}(1/K^{3/4}) as opposed to the ğ’ªâ€‹(1/K)ğ’ª1ğ¾\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{K}) for wireless FL without sampling [26] and ğ’ªâ€‹(1/K)ğ’ª1ğ¾\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{K}) for FL with orthogonal transmission and user sampling [25] (see Table I). Clearly, when both wireless aggregation and user sampling are employed, we can obtain additional benefit in terms of central privacy. We also plot the central privacy level of the proposed scheme against other variations (see Fig. 2(a)).

references: In Fig. 4 and 5, we show the impact of sampling probability on the training accuracy. First, we observe that a higher pğ‘p leads to a higher accuracy for the model. Next, in Table II(a)ğ‘(a), we observe that, for the uniform case with L=1ğ¿1L=1, the central DP leakage decreases as pğ‘p increases, which contradicts with the intuition that higher pğ‘p leads to higher leakage. However, let pk,t=p,âˆ€k,tsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ‘for-allğ‘˜ğ‘¡p_{k,t}=p,\forall k,t in (13), i.e.,

we can see that the behavior of Ïµc,tsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘ğ‘¡\epsilon_{c,t} depends on two terms: p/(1âˆ’Î´â€²)ğ‘1superscriptğ›¿â€²p/(1-\delta^{\prime}) and expâ¡(c/Kâ€‹(pâˆ’Î²))ğ‘ğ¾ğ‘ğ›½\exp(c/\sqrt{K(p-\beta)}). As pğ‘p increases, the first term increases and the second term decreases. For a certain range of cğ‘c, the second term dominates, therefore, Ïµc,tsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘ğ‘¡\epsilon_{c,t}, as a whole, decreases. This is due to the fact that, since perturbation noises get aggregated over the wireless channel, the privacy is enhanced. Hence, users are encouraged to participate more when cğ‘c belongs to this range. In general, cğ‘c depends on Ïƒk,t,L,Î´â„“subscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¿subscriptğ›¿â„“\sigma_{k,t},L,\delta_{\ell}, and cğ‘c for Fig. 4(a) and Table II(a)ğ‘(a) falls in the range that allows the second term to dominate as pğ‘p increases. We also demonstrate the case when the first term dominates, i.e., L=0.1ğ¿0.1L=0.1 for this set of parameters. We can see that the central DP leakage increases as pğ‘p increases from Table II(b)ğ‘(b). When cğ‘c is in this range, the amplification of privacy is not enough to outweigh the disadvantage of participating more. Thus, the intuition that higher pğ‘p leads to higher leakage holds. This can also be seen in Fig. 7 that the first term dominates when c=2ğ‘2c=2 and the second term dominates when c=4,6,8ğ‘468c=4,6,8. Similar trends can be found in Table III.

From Table II, we can also see that channel aware sampling achieves 85.27%percent85.2785.27\% and 84.33%percent84.3384.33\% testing accuracy, which is lower than those of uniform sampling with p=0.9ğ‘0.9p=0.9. This is due to the choice of hthsubscriptâ„thh_{\text{th}}. By reducing hthsubscriptâ„thh_{\text{th}}, we can improve the accuracy of the channel aware sampling.
Another interesting observation is that, while channel aware sampling suffers slightly from higher central DP leakages, it does achieve relatively high testing accuracy and low LDP leakage with significant less average number of participants compare to uniform sampling with p=0.9ğ‘0.9p=0.9.
